--- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On 
> > Behalf Of sarathy_groups
> 
> > finally I got the count of the table using a query (select 
> > count(*) from <table name> )after executing tat pl/sql 
> > procedure to see whether its 0 or not
> > 
> > and assertEquals(query=="0",true) for junit testing,
> 
> You shouldn't be using == on strings.  Instead:
> 
> assertEquals(query, "0");
> 
> seems more correct to me.

Or rather

assertEquals("0", query);

to get an error message which correctly identifies which is the
expected value, and which is the actual value.  JUnit error messages
refer to the first argument as the expected value, and the second as
the actual value.  (As in, "I was expecting 'foo' here, but got
'bar'.")

- Jim Yingst
